awd_titl_txt: Hazards SEES: Improved prediction of geomagnetic disturbances, geomagnetically induced currents, and their impacts on power distribution systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical summary

Significant solar storms cause disturbances in Earth's magnetic field (geomagnetic disturbances or GMDs), which in turn induce currents in electric power transmission systems.  These geomagnetically induced currents (GICs) pose a potentially catastrophic threat to the power distribution systems on which society depends.  For example, a solar storm in March 1989 triggered GICs that caused cascading transformer failures and widespread blackouts that affected millions of people in Quebec.  This project is developing a quantitative understanding of the impacts that GICs and GMDs can have on the power grid, which is critical to helping the utility industry plan ahead and reduce risk.   Through developing a comprehensive modeling and analysis approach, beginning with space weather and ending with impacts to grid operation, we are driving new useful analytic tools and insights.   We are also improving the scientific community's understanding of the Earth through analysis of coupling between direct magnetic field measurements and transformer neutral currents.  Finally, our outreach efforts are providing information to the public about critical concepts related to the sun, the upper atmosphere, space weather hazards, Earth's geophysical properties, and the power grid.
 
Technical Summary

Our project is intended to improve the scientific understanding of the processes governing the impacts on our power distribution system of severe solar storms. The team is studying the relationship between solar wind drivers and magnetic field perturbations on the ground, developing improved models of induced electric fields, and enhancing prediction capabilities for GIC hazards. The team is developing algorithms that both advance the science of induced electric fields and operate as a predictive tool of GIC hazards in the bulk power system, including transformer heating and damage and loss of voltage stability. Impact models are being developed, enhanced, and validated to provide better prediction of the effects of GMDs on power systems for both real-time response and longer-term resilience.

por.por_cntn:
Major solar storms can cause disturbances in Earth's magnetic field (geomagnetic disturbances or GMDs), which in turn induce currents in electric power transmission systems. These geomagnetically induced currents (GICs) pose a potentially catastrophic threat to the power grid.

Intellectual Merit

As proposed, our project has made significant strides in improving the scientific understanding of the GMD phenomena and its impact on the electric power grid, from 1) the solar wind to 2) magnetic field perturbations, to 3) induced electric fields, and 4) GICs. We developed algorithms and tools at each stage of this process to model the interdependencies. This $2,670,000 award was a complex, multi-disciplinary, and multi-institute project, involving instrumentation, industry engagement, and educational activities apart from research and development.

For the solar wind part of the project, we were able to develop methods to make 30-minute time-varying predictions of surface magnetic field variations for strong events with a clear solar wind signature. 

This project also funded the deployment of seven magnetometers to measure the earth’s magnetic field throughout the US namely in IL, TX, MN, CT, ME, CO, and OH. The goal was to fill in the measurement gaps with existing USGS magnetic observatories especially in the middle of the country, and provide finer magnetic field measurements for improved analysis. 

From these magnetic fields, we tested, validated and used different ground conductivity models to make significant improvements in the calculation of electric fields. Real-time electric fields are being calculated from this network and communicated to utilities in the respective footprints. An archive of storm time data, including significant storms in August and September 2018, is being prepared for long-term data access. 

Next, we enhanced our modeling of the power grid for GMD simulations, and used the calculated electric fields as inputs to simulate GICs. Comparing them with GICs measured by utilities in their transformers helped us ensure our models are accurate, and can be used for predictions or decision-making.

We also implemented model to assess GIC impacts on the grid such as transformer heating. Another key component of this project was the development of several algorithms to mitigate the effect of GICs such as 1) transmission line switching, and 2) optimal placement of GIC blocking devices in the system to reduce either the GICs themselves or the reactive losses they cause. Several papers have been published by the project team on this topic.

Finally, we implemented these models in a real-time environment to mimic how power grid operators may respond to actual GMDs. This involved developing effective visualization and control techniques to enable the operator to take quick and effective decisions to mitigate the impacts.

 

Broader Impact

Through the scientific and engineering development in this project, we have improved GMD risk prediction, assessment, and mitigation methodologies. As GMDs can have severe and long lasting impacts on the grid, such advancements can help to secure critical infrastructure like the power grid, and benefit the society at large.

The project has served a number of educational, outreach, and professional development causes. Several graduate students and a post-doc at four different institutes (UIUC, TAMU, CSU, and VT) were supported by this project, including a big percentage of female students, and four female co-PI’s. GMD modeling has also been included in the some of the course curriculum at TAMU (e.g., ECEN 615) which is a recent development partly due to this project. Apart from academic courses, a professional short course on GMD was also created and offered at TAMU in 2019, with team members serving as three of the five instructors. The target audience was utility industry, government and regulatory agencies, and graduate students.  

An important aspect of the project was to educate students and the public about the sun, space weather, electromagnetism, and the power grid. Part of this involves the creation and dissemination of age appropriate and engaging classroom-ready activities that explore the changing and dynamic sun and the effects of space weather on the electric grid. Many of the materials are available on our website (gmd.mste.illinois.edu). Topics included magnets and the relationships between electricity and magnetism, space weather and the dynamic sun, our electricity delivery system, and risks geomagnetically induced currents pose to the power grid. We have also conducted classroom teacher workshops, and participated in the Girls Learning Electrical Engineering (GLEE) camp at the University of Illinois and the Illinois Summer Academy camp to introduce high school students to the electric power grid and to the impact of solar storms on our society including the power grid.

Finally, throughout this project, we engaged with electric utilities for GMD assessments and data access, regulatory agencies such as NERC to understand research needs to meet reliability requirements, and worked with commercial software developers for technology transfer of our algorithms and tools for widespread use and impact.

Modified by: Jonathan J Makela
